title: Rats!
text:
Credit to MH Gail, TJ Santner, and CC Brown (1980). “An analysis of comparative carcinogenesis experiments based on multiple times to tumor”. Biometrics 36, 255–266.





Call:
survdiff(formula = survObj ~ rats2.2$trt)

               N Observed Expected (O-E)^2/E (O-E)^2/V
rats2.2$trt=0 25       25     17.3      3.37      6.12
rats2.2$trt=1 23       21     28.7      2.04      6.12

 Chisq= 6.1  on 1 degrees of freedom, p= 0.01 


The survival curves illustrate the different survival outcomes between rats in the control group, trt=0, and those who received treatment, trt=1. To determine whether the hazard functions of the 2 groups are statistically significant, a log-rank test is performed, and the resulting p-value provides sufficient evidence to reject the null hypotheses, implying that treatment was effective.

title: Cats!
text:
Where does the fastest cat in the UK like to hang out?
Credit to: Kays R, Dunn RR, Parsons AW, Mcdonald B, Perkins T, Powers S, Shell L, McDonald JL, Cole H, Kikillus H, Woods L, Tindle H, Roetman P (2020) The small home ranges and large local ecological impacts of pet cats. Animal Conservation. doi:10.1111/acv.12563
This post was inspired by the Tidy Tuesday submission for 2023-01-31.




leaflet()%>% 
  addProviderTiles("OpenStreetMap.Mapnik") %>% 
  addCircleMarkers(lng=g2_t$location_long,
                   lat=g2_t$location_lat,
                   popup = timestamp,
                   color="purple",radius = 2)





The cat with the tag Gracie_2 was found to be the cat with the highest ground speed in this study. Her location information is plotted in a simple leaflet map. She appears to reside in Camborne mainly but can be found in the surrounding areas as well.

ds<-read_csv("IKEA_SA_Furniture_Web_Scrapings_sss.csv")

New names:
Rows: 3694 Columns: 14
── Column specification
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr
(7): name, category, old_price, link, other_colors, short_description, d... dbl
(6): ...1, item_id, price, depth, height, width lgl (1): sellable_online
ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ
Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
• `` -> `...1`

tableds<-ds %>%
  filter(category=="Tables & desks") %>%
  select(-category,-...1,-old_price) %>%
  mutate(price_usd=round(price*0.266,2)) %>% # Conversion rate from SR to USD 4/24/2020
  arrange(desc(price)) %>%
  select(-price) %>%
  head(10)
  
tableds

# … with 1 more variable: price_usd <dbl>, and abbreviated variable names
#   ¹​sellable_online, ²​other_colors, ³​short_description, ⁴​designer



#names(tableds)

tableds %>%
  gt() %>%
  tab_header(
    title = "IKEA Tables and Desks Saudi Arabia",
    subtitle = "Top 10 Most Expensive Tables as of 4/20/2020"
  ) %>%
  fmt_currency(
    columns = price_usd,
    currency = "USD"
  ) %>%
  cols_label(item_id="ID",
             name="Name",
             sellable_online="Sellable Online",
             link="Link",
             other_colors="Other Colors",
             short_description="Description",
             designer="Designer",
             depth="Depth",
             height="Height",
             width="Width") %>%
  tab_spanner(
    label="Dimensions",
    columns = c(depth,
                height,
                width)
  )

  filter(category=="Tables & desks") %>%
  select(-category,-...1,-old_price) %>%
